The reason that the game crashed is pretty easy to pinpoint.  A level 5
mage with 20 intelligence has more mana than a level 1 mage with 20
intelligence.  Gladiator was programmed in C, which has limits to the
variables -- when these limits are crossed, the variables plunge into the
realm of negatives.  Various calculations that the game performs could
cause program upsets that causes it to crash.

The reason that your editor and game crashes when your grid is too
large is probably because the game does not allocate enough memory
from the heap to hold the data effectively.  This anomoly is, once
again, good recipe for a crash.

The reasons behind this are probably because you're pushing the game
to its limits.  I believe that, fundamentally, gladiator should be able to

operate on a 386 without too much hampering by the system's
resources (or lack thereof).  I think that this is how the game was
originally designed without enormous scenarios being taken into mind.

This touches again on my proposal that the level designers out there
design scenarios with a starting team in mind -- without the
expectation that the player's characters will reach levels in the
hundreds.
